intro: Sclerocactus mesae-verdae, commonly known as the Chihuahuan desert hedgehog cactus, is a rare and striking member of the Cactaceae family native to the Chihuahuan Desert in Mexico and the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its spiny, cylindrical stems that are often covered in a white, waxy coating, which helps reduce water loss in its arid environment. The plant produces yellow flowers during the spring, which are typically short-lived but attract pollinators such as bees and moths. Sclerocactus mesae-verdae is adapted to extreme heat and drought, with a slow growth rate and long lifespan, making it a resilient yet vulnerable species. Due to habitat loss and over-collection, it is classified as endangered in some regions.
